channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: After 167 Years in New York, a Priceless Coin Collection Heads to Toledo
item.description: The doubloons, dollars and denarii of the American Numismatic Society will leave their overlooked home in Manhattan for a more welcoming headquarters on the campus of the Toledo Museum of Art.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry and Photographs By Todd Heisler
item.media:description: The American Numismatic Society has one of the world’s great coin collections, but few people currently see it.

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Review: Two Besties Till the End
item.description: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande return to Oz for the second part of Jon M. Chu’s maximalist adaptation of the Broadway musical.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure,’ Documentary About U.F.O.s, Gets a Congressional Audience
item.description: “The Age of Disclosure,” a documentary featuring government and military officials, was screened for a bipartisan group of members of the House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Blumenthal and Leslie Kean
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director Dan Farah at a showing of his film, “The Age of Disclosure,” in Washington.

item.title: Ruth Asawa Turned Wire Into Her Lifeline
item.description: Her undulating looped-wire sculptures and drawings of flowers hint at personal depths, in a major retrospective at MoMA.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon
item.category: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
item.media:credit: Ramona Jingru Wang for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Art can only be taught by artists,” Asawa once said. “If a non-artist teaches a subject called art, it is nonart.”

item.title: The Grand Ole Opry at 100
item.description: As the country music institution celebrates a century of its radio broadcast, listen to how the show defined the culture — and was reshaped by it — decade by decade.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren

item.title: Frida Kahlo Portrait Sells for $55 Million, Setting Her Auction Record
item.description: The surrealistic self-portrait was made in 1940, a turbulent year in the Mexican artist’s life as her health and marriage deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Tim F. Schneider
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bidding for Frida Kahlo, “El sueño (La cama),” or “The dream (The bed),” at Sotheby’s auction house in Manhattan. It sold for $55 million at auction Thursday night, breaking the artist’s record.

item.title: Told to Avoid D.E.I., Arts Groups Are Declining Grants Instead
item.description: Even with arts funding at risk, some organizations are rejecting federal money because of censorship concerns.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Netflix Has a New House in the Suburbs: Come In and Chill
item.description: After a string of successful events and activities, the streamer has opened its first permanent home for branded fun, at a mall near Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Michelle Gustafson
item.category: Netflix House Philadelphia (King of Prussia, Pa)
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times

item.title: Superman Comic Sets Auction Record, Selling for $9.12 Million
item.description: A family’s forgotten copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was sold by Heritage Auctions.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:credit: Heritage Auctions
item.media:description: A high-grade copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was discovered by a family last year and sold for $9.12 million at auction.

item.title: In a Reimagined ‘Our Town,’ Dance and Poetry Run for the Woods
item.description: In “My Town,” Jack Ferver’s one-person take on the Wilder classic with hints of “Wisconsin Death Trip,” movement and storytelling are deftly intertwined.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I was really looking for the truth of the dance for this piece,” they said. “I wanted to push something about dance picking up where language drops off as far as I possibly could.”

item.title: Arthur Jafa Crafts a Mixtape from MoMA’s Art
item.description: In “Artist’s Choice: Arthur Jafa,” the artist mines the museum’s vaults for an exhibition that gives new meaning to what he found there.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: ‘Train Dreams’ Review: Life, Understood in Reverse
item.description: Joel Edgerton stars in a gorgeous film based on Denis Johnson’s celebrated novella about a laborer in the Pacific Northwest.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Rental Family’ Review: Brendan Fraser, Lost in Impersonation
item.description: Brendan Fraser is quietly endearing in this fish-out-of-water tale of an American actor in Tokyo who accepts some highly unusual assignments.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: Theater as a Safe Space? ‘Practice’ Demolishes That Idea.
item.description: Nazareth Hassan’s darkly witty satire follows an imperious director who pushes his eager actors to extremes.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman

item.title: ‘Two Strangers’ Review: Meeting Cute, Toting Baggage
item.description: The effervescent musical, a new London import, delivers lavishly on the promise of a rom-com: laughter, escape and fantasy.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Sara Krulwich
item.category: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York) (Play)
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sammy Tutty, left, plays the irrepressible Dougal opposite Christiani Pitts as the no-nonsense Robin in “Two Strangers Carry a Cake Across New York” at the Longacre Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: CIA Kryptos Auction: Anonymous Bidder Pays Nearly $1 Million for Secret to Decode Sculpture
item.description: The creator of the Kryptos panels, Jim Sanborn, sought to unburden himself of the puzzle, and then discovered before an auction he had archived its solution in the Smithsonian.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Kevin Wolf/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jim Sanborn, the artist who created the Kryptos sculpture, at the International Spy Museum in Washington earlier this month.

item.title: David Bellos, 80, Dies; Wrestled French Wordplay Into English
item.description: He translated nearly 30 books, including novels by Georges Perec, a master of linguistic games, and Ismail Kadare.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Who Owns This Sentence? A History of Copyrights and Wrongs (Book)

item.title: Richard Lamparski, Author of ‘Whatever Became Of …?’ Books, Dies at 93
item.description: He turned an obsession with forgotten stars into a popular series, long before “Where Are They Now?” features became ubiquitous.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: After the Louvre Heist, the Museum’s President Defends Her Tenure
item.description: In one of her very few interviews since the museum heist, Laurence des Cars said the plan would increase much-needed security, but critics say it is too focused on new construction.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Elaine Sciolino
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laurence des Cars, the Louvre’s president, in the museum in 2023.

item.title: Senate Democrats Investigate Kennedy Center Deals With Trump Allies
item.description: Under Richard Grenell, the performing arts center has given steep discounts to CPAC and FIFA, signed contracts with administration associates and spent lavishly on friends.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Grenell at a White House dinner for the Kennedy Center board in May. Since he was tapped to lead the center, it has become something resembling a private club for the president’s friends and supporters.

item.title: ‘The Family Plan 2’ Review: A Relaxing Vacation? Maybe Not.
item.description: Mark Wahlberg and Michelle Monaghan return in a better executed, equally goofball sequel about a family’s tangles with organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter’ Review: When Fame Recedes
item.description: A documentary tracks the highs and lows of the 1990s fitness guru, now a food delivery driver in Las Vegas.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter (Movie)

item.title: ‘Sisu: Road to Revenge’ Review: Slapstick Rambo
item.description: In this sequel to the 2023 exploitation film, blood-splattered inanity becomes a delirium of popcorn fun.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Cutting Through Rocks’ Review: The Only Way Out
item.description: A documentary about Sara Shahverdi, the first woman elected to the council of her village in Iran, is propelled by her no-nonsense resourcefulness.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Linden

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure’ Review: Release the Extraterrestrial Files
item.description: A documentary argues that the U.S. government needs to divulge what it knows about the phenomena formerly called U.F.O.s.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Cactus Pears’ Review: Finding Intimacy Amid Grief
item.description: This understated Indian drama follows closeted gay man gingerly initiating a romance with an old friend.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Prepares for Hurricane Epstein
item.description: Kimmel wondered if President Trump might “pull a Taylor Swift and give us ‘The Epstein Files: Donnie’s Version.’”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Newly Discovered Bach Pieces Are the Fruits of Decades of Detective Work
item.description: A pair of organ works that scholars believe were written by a teenage Johann Sebastian Bach were premiered in Leipzig this week and added to the composer’s official catalog.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse, via Bach Archive/AFP Via Getty Image
item.media:description: The two pieces were premiered by Ton Koopman and given their own numbers in the catalog of Bach’s works: BWV 1178 and BWV 1179.

item.title: Believe It or Not, That $12 Million Gold Toilet Was Bought by … Ripley’s
item.description: The entertainment company plans on displaying the toilet, saying its team is exploring “whether visitors may someday be allowed to use it.”
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ripley’s Believe It or Not, which paid $12.1 million for the toilet on Tuesday, said that “finding the unbelievable is our business.”

item.title: Holiday Gift Ideas: What to Get an Ex, a Sick Parent and More Recommendations
item.description: Plus: what to get a sick mother, a minimalist son and more holiday present advice from T Magazine.

item.title: How Magdalene Odundo Makes Ceramics Seem Like Bodies in Motion
item.description: For more than five decades, the ceramist Magdalene Odundo has been making abstract, time-intensive vessels that recall bodies in motion.
item.dc:creator: Zoey Poll

item.title: Meryl Streep and More Stars Toast Tom Hanks in ‘This World of Tomorrow’
item.description: A crowd that included Meryl Streep, Martin Short and Steve Martin packed the Shed for the actor’s new show, “This World of Tomorrow.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Ye Fan
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times

item.title: Alice and Ellen Kessler, ’60s Singing Sensations, Die at 89
item.description: The twin sisters from Germany, who were nightclub stars and regular guests on international variety shows, chose to end their lives together.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Karl Mittenzwei/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Kesslers at a news conference in 1997, presenting excerpts from a show based on their autobiography, “Eins Und Eins Ist Eins” (“One Plus One Is One”).

item.title: U.K. Vows to Ban Resale of Concert Tickets Above Face Value
item.description: The move aims to prevent “touts,” or scalpers, from charging exorbitant prices for sought-after shows.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: An Oasis concert in Wales this summer. British regulators opened an investigation after Oasis fans saw some seats on Ticketmaster more than double in cost from their advertised price.

item.title: Review: Strauss’s ‘Arabella’ Returns to the Met Opera
item.description: The latest revival of Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal’s final opera was a night of promising debuts and mixed success.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: These Books Were Judged by Their A.I. Covers, and Disqualified
item.description: A New Zealand book competition dropped two of a publisher’s books because they had A.I.-generated covers. The publisher and the designer pushed back.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: This Play Recruited Actors With Anorexia. Was That Ethical?
item.description: Some psychologists and parents argued that it risked glamorizing the condition, but one performer described the experience as empowering: “Onstage, I can be who I really am.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: ‘Sacramento,’ ‘Happy Christmas’ and More Streaming Gems
item.description: This month’s off-the-radar streaming suggestions include modest but moving indie comedy-dramas, documentaries profiling comedy legends and more.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.category: The One and Only Dick Gregory (Movie)

item.title: Black Flag’s Latest Reboot Has Everyone Talking (Even Greg Ginn)
item.description: At 71, Ginn has remade his hardcore institution once again — this time with zoomer-aged bandmates. Is it a punk statement or karaoke?
item.dc:creator: Nate Rogers
item.media:credit: Eli Durst for The New York Times

item.title: After the Death of Two Titans, Where Are the Next Giant Art Patrons?
item.description: With the passing of Leonard A. Lauder and Agnes Gund amid financial headwinds, arts organizations worry that the cultural megadonor may be a thing of the past.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times

item.title: The Debate Over Colorblind Casting Isn’t Settled After All
item.description: A Black Hedda Gabler on film and a white Korean robot onstage are sending mixed signals about the status of cultural diversity and representation.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: How to Talk About Money in Your Relationship, According to a Personal Finance Coach
item.description: Ramit Sethi, a personal finance author and coach, offers four lessons to help you stop arguing about money in your relationship and start living a “rich life” together.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset: Photo by Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: George Clooney, Adam Sandler and Noah Baumbach on Fame and ‘Jay Kelly’
item.description: The stars and the director look back on their days trying to break into the industry and how failure was part of the equation.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noah Baumbach with Sandler and Clooney in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Celebrates ‘Epstein Rockin’ Eve’
item.description: “Stay up for a ball drop you’re going to want to miss,” the “Late Show” host said as Congress voted for the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘This World of Tomorrow’ Review: Tom Hanks Is Back in Town
item.description: The movie star plays a man from the future at the 1939 New York World’s Fair in an adaptation of some of his stories. Kelli O’Hara shines as his love interest.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Hanks, Kayli Carter and Kelli O’Hara in “This World of Tomorrow” at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: At $236 Million, Klimt Piece Is Second Most Expensive Painting Sold at Auction
item.description: At $236.4 million, a portrait by Gustav Klimt is the second most expensive painting sold at auction, while Maurizio Cattelan’s golden toilet drew $12.1 million.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Modern art history: The auctioneer at Sotheby’s, Oliver Barker, hammered down a final bid on a portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Klimt.

item.title: ‘Meet the Cartozians’ Review: Who Gets to Be White in America?
item.description: Talene Monahon’s captivating play uses a 1925 court decision to explore what identity means to Armenians here (a certain reality TV star included).
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: The cast of “Meet the Cartozians,” from left: Will Brill, Tamara Sevunts, Andrea Martin, Raffi Barsoumian and Nael Nacer at the Pershing Square Signature Center in Manhattan.

item.title: On ‘Finally Over It,’ Summer Walker Is R&B’s Maestro of the Funny Side of Heartbreak
item.description: On “Finally Over It,” the singer and songwriter rolls her eyes and brings in like-minded cynics for tracks that recall the soulful sounds of the ’90s.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Scott Legato/Getty Images
item.media:description: On Summer Walker’s most powerful songs, she sings in a manner so offhand, it’s as if she forgot it was a song altogether rather than a bemused berating.

item.title: Obsessed With ‘Wicked’? Try 9 More Songs From Beloved Musicals.
item.description: If you’ve got Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande on repeat, add these songs from “Rent,” “Hadestown,” “13” and more to the rotation.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman

item.title: Artists Pick Their Favorite Films About Artists
item.description: Movies with artist-protagonists are known to be disappointing. These pass muster and even inspire.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin

item.title: ‘Lahppon/Lost’ Was a Hit in Oslo. But in the Sami Heartland?
item.description: The Norwegian National Ballet was nervous about taking a new work about a Sami uprising to the area where the historical event took place.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend and David B. Torch
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times

item.title: Public Theater’s ‘Initiative’: A Coming-of-Age Play Unfolds Over Five Hours
item.description: The characters in Else Went’s quiet Off Broadway debut at the Public Theater try to make sense of the world while coming-of-age in the early aughts.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Corzine

item.title: ‘Selena y Los Dinos’ Review: Still Dreaming of You
item.description: In this look back at the singer Selena, the director Isabel Castro presents home video footage and photographs that have not been seen in other documentaries.
item.dc:creator: Chris Azzopardi

item.title: Vanity Fair’s New Hollywood Issue, First Under New Editor, Is All About Men
item.description: Mark Guiducci gave his first issue of Vanity Fair over to the guys.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: Body Slams, Curated: Pro Wrestling Enters Its Museum Era
item.description: The over-the-top spectacle has been slicing into the art world, with gallery shows, performances and a forthcoming major exhibition.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Marcus Maddox
item.category: Pioneer Works Center for Art and Innovation (Brooklyn, NY)
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: George Benjamin and Pierre-Laurent Aimard: Friendship in Music
item.description: The composer George Benjamin and the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard met as students. In a new piece, they perform at the keyboard together.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pierre-Laurent Aimard, left, and George Benjamin.

item.title: The Art of Britain’s Windrush Generation Has Never Felt More Relevant
item.description: At a time of rising xenophobia and nativism, their work examines the meeting of different cultures, and their own right to belong.
item.dc:creator: Aatish Taseer

item.title: ‘25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee’ Review: A Delightful Competition
item.description: Adult actors play fierce middle-school spellers in a wonderful revival of William Finn and Rachel Sheinkin’s musical.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.category: The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee (Play)
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Jasmine Amy Rodgers, Leana Rae Concepcion, Autumn Best, Justin Cooley, Philippe Arroyo and Kevin McHale in “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” at New World Stages in Manhattan.

item.title: How Much Sex, Drugs and Violence Can Be in a PG-13 Movie?
item.description: The movie ratings board has pulled back the curtain on how it approaches hot-button topics, including nudity, marijuana and guns.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: Daniele Rustioni, Old-School Conductor, Joins the Met Opera
item.description: Daniele Rustioni is already busy as the Met’s new principal guest conductor, with three shows onstage this fall.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times

item.title: New to Cyberpunk Books? Here’s Where to Start.
item.description: The science fiction writer Chloe Gong recommends new and classic books that push the boundaries of the genre, with plenty of techno thrills.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gong
item.media:credit: Author photo by One Grid Studio

item.title: A.I. Video Is Threatening Our Ability to Trust Documentaries
item.description: A combination of technological developments and market forces is undermining the trust between viewer and filmmaker. What’s at stake is history itself.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
